blocks.text: Summary of the ACR algorithms. Use the flowcharts below for full details.

items: > 15 mmFollow-up MRI; if stable, consider second follow-up then stop
Symptoms of increased intracranial pressure or mass effect, or imaging red flags (tectal signal change, hydrocephalus, aqueduct mass effect)Neurosurgical consult

Incidental means no symptoms such as nausea/vomiting, papilledema, visual disturbance, Parinaud's syndrome, hemiparesis, hemisensory changes, vertigo, syncope, migraine, or seizures; isolated headache alone does not trigger consult.
If tectal signal change, hydrocephalus, or aqueduct mass effect develops on any imaging, refer for neurosurgical consultation.
>= 15 mmMRI follow-up preferred; if stable, manage as >15 mm simple cyst on MRI
Symptoms of increased intracranial pressure or mass effect, or imaging red flags (tectal hypoattenuation, hydrocephalus, aqueduct mass effect)Neurosurgical consult

Incidental means no symptoms such as nausea/vomiting, papilledema, visual disturbance, Parinaud's syndrome, hemiparesis, hemisensory changes, vertigo, syncope, migraine, or seizures; isolated headache alone does not trigger consult.
If tectal signal abnormality or hypoattenuation on CT, hydrocephalus, or aqueduct mass effect develops on any imaging, refer for neurosurgical consultation.

blocks.text: Based on the ACR Incidental Findings Committee guidance.

items: Recommendations cover incidental pineal cysts detected on CT of the head or MRI of the brain.
The pathways focus on asymptomatic incidental findings and standard follow-up decisions.
Use the flowcharts below to match the imaging modality and apply the recommended next steps.
